text:
Does anyone have any suggestions on *how to create blog post image headers more quickly / still have a unified aesthetic?*

We have a graphic designer, but she has a lot on her plate and often asks me to push back the deadlines on blog posts... which I don't really want to do based on traffic goals :stuck_out_tongue: Before she started I was just creating images in Canva, which I _could_ keep doing but it doesn't look as professional as I would like, and no one else on our team has enough graphic design experience to actually create anything more elaborate than that either.
<@ULJBEFSJJ> what style are they?
<https://www.wildapricot.com/blogs/newsblog/2019/08/29/volunteer-engagement>

text: I'm not a graphic artist (quite the opposite) - so I've struggled with this myself. That being said, I'm not entirely sure that the style of the blog headers matches the rest of the site. Is there any possibility that you could use a different style?
Like work with a graphic designer to come up with a better "design system" to do the blog headers
We're in the process of redesigning our whole site, so it will soon match this better — plus, this is the style she decided to go with when I told her she could do whatever :woman-shrugging:

<@ULJBEFSJJ> templates templates templates. Even if its your designer showing you 2-3 standard photoshop filters you can use on stock illustrations or photos. I can share an example we use at InVision in a moment…
Yeah I was wondering if that would be a good way to do it. I'd love an example!
Google Slides or PPT. Adjust the dimensions to suit the needed image sizing. Create a standard set of templates. Export the slide as a PNG or JPEG.

so we actually havent rolled these out yet but you can see: we identified the top image needs. For us it was:
- portraits
- section breaks
- quotes
- showing screen designs (that’s what our blog is about!)
so we outlined what we would need with examples and sent to designer (some examples from that doc):
our designers took those and made us these templates:
I have them in Sketch and InVision Studio now moving forward
we used similar process to update social assets as well, check the header on our twitter page and compare to the above

happy to go into details
^ Love that. SO much.

hey everyone, I just deleted a few blog posts from my website and now i’ve redirected all the urls to my blog root url.
All those pages also had AMP versions. My question is: should I also redirect the amp versions to the blog root url? Does it have to be an AMP page?

no reason not to redirect the AMP pages (to any other URL).

the AMP pages should've had a canonical tag pointing to the primary URL (that's how Google manages indexation of both versions), so if Google sees AMP page > canonical to primary URL > primary URL redirect, it might abide by that, but there's no harm in adding another 301 just to make sure.

Google is on record saying that they treat generic redirects as 404s (not 301s), so if you have a relevant post to point those deleted posts toward (rather than just /blog/), that might help preserve the existing link equity, if there is any.
That was super helpful, <@UJDPMTREY>. Thanks!

I'd add that illustrations are very hard to keep up with. You need a dedicated freelancer just for that and you must stay weeks ahead or they won't get it done. I've switched to something similar to what Sean said with stock photos, and it's much easier to keep up with. Set a design theme with filters and go from there
